Award.AwardTitle: Observations and Predictions of Sand Grain Size Variability and Morphodynamics on Beaches
Award.AbstractNarration:
At first glance many sandy beaches appear to consist of sand that is all the same size. Most numerical models of the changing shape of the beach also assume uniform grain size across the model domain. However, even small changes in the size of the grains can have a large effect on whether or not the sand will move and how much sand can be transported. The hypothesis for the present study is that small grain size variations can determine whether and where a beach is more likely to erode. As part of this research, the variability of sand grain size will be measured, both in space on a natural beach and in time through storms and calm periods. Correlations between the spatial and temporal variability of sand size and changing beach morphology will be examined, with the goal of determining whether variations in grain size are important in the development of patterns of erosion and accretion. For example, coarser sediments are often observed in rip channels while finer sediments are found on the shoals between channels. It has also been observed that finer sediments are found high on the intertidal beach and offshore in sand bars, whereas grain sizes in the surf zone are much coarser. In addition, this coarse-sediment region moves up and down the beach with the rise and fall of the tides. To make measurements of sand grain size, a digital imaging system (DIS) will be used that consists of a digital camera with a macro lens in an underwater housing. Images of sand are processed to give estimates of mean grain size. With the DIS, many more measurements of grain size can be obtained than is logistically feasible with traditional sediment sampling techniques. As part of this study, high-resolution grain size surveys will be conducted regularly. These observations will be compared with predictions of the motion of different sand size classes from state-of-the-artmodels of waves, currents and beach changes. The results will be used to explore the physical processes moving different size classes, to assess the importance of spatial and temporal grain size variability in making accurate predictions of sediment transport and to improve prediction of beach morphodynamics for a wide range of environmental conditions.

The present research will contribute to improved knowledge and prediction of coastal changes. Predictions of this type are presently used by federal, state, and local governments to provide coastal planning and management, for military operations, and by scientists to better understand the physical processes responsible for moving sand and other materials in the coastal region. In addition, the resulting improved model will lead to better predictions for sediment transport and shoreline changes on coasts threatened by extreme waves and sea level rise. A large percentage of the world's population lives within the coastal region and a better understanding and predictive capability of the physical processes affecting the coasts will allow planning, management and mitigation for safer coasts worldwide.

POR.DRECONTENT:
At first glance, sand grains on a beach might look like they are all the same, but in fact they vary in size, shape and in mineralogy (what they are made of). To be able to predict how beaches change (erosion and deposition), models need information about the grains (because small grains are easier to move than larger grains). Until recently, most modelers have assumed a single average grain size. In this study, we examined the details of grain size variations, both in space and in time, and how those variations effect model predictions of beach changes.

We estimated grain size (Gallagher et al. 2011) from macro (very close-up) images of sand taken with a camera in an underwater housing. Grain size was mapped over large areas of a beach in Truc Vert, France. We found that spatial grain size variations depend on the larger-scale morphology (beach forms and shapes) and its changes. For example, grains were coarser in rip channels, where strong currents can pick up and move finer sediments away. Those finer sediments are moved (via rip circulation patterns, MacMahan et al. 2010) onto the shallow shoals, where breaking waves redistribute them. Finer sediments can be deposited on the beach by waves, and then wind can act during low tide to move the exposed sediments up into the dunes. So, waves, currents and wind create grain size patterns and the patterns are dynamic and change as the morphology changes.

Next, we measured grain size on a profile across a beach in Monterey, CA. We wanted to look at how fast grain size patterns change and respond to changing waves and tides. We found that a coarse patch exists in the crashing waves at the water line (known as the shore-break), and that the patch marches up and down the beach with the tide. This coarse patch is created by the powerful shore-break, which continually reworks the sediment, removing finer material, leaving coarse material behind. We hypothesized that this coarse patch actually protects a beach from erosion. This armor is the result of the natural variation in grain size that is not usually considered.

These observations have been used to drive an existing, well-developed model for waves, currents, sand transport, and morphology changes called Xbeach. We employed a little-used component of Xbeach that allows the transport of many different grain sizes to be predicted at once. The model predicted the transport and redistribution of different grain sizes and the coarsening of the sands immediately under the energetic shore-break (Reniers et al. 2013), a region that has been poorly predicted in many published modeling efforts.

Recently, we have been focusing on trying to measure and predict what is beneath the sand surface. If the beach erodes, what sediment layers are encountered? If deposition takes place, how are sediments layered? Do we need to know and understand these layers to predict beach changes (e.g. erosion during storms)? Can grain size variations and stratigraphy help protect beaches from erosion? This study can have an impact on our understanding of coastal changes in the face of rising sea level and increased storm impacts on open coastlines.
